# What are these sounds?

## Reading Material

https://strudel.cc/learn/samples/

## What are these sounds?

Listen to this pattern:

Now listen to this one and notice the difference:

[https://strudel.cc/#c2V0Y3BtKDk4LzQpCgovLyBEZWZpbmUgZWFjaCBpbnN0cnVtZW50IHBhdHRlcm4KY29uc3Qga2ljayA9IHMoIltiZCBiZCB%2BIH5dW34gfiBiZCB%2BXVtiZCBiZCB%2BIGJkXVt%2BIH4gfiB%2BXSIpCmNvbnN0IGNsb3NlZEhhdCA9IHMoIltoaCBoaCBoaCBoaF1bIGhoIGhoIGhoIGhoXVtoaCBoaCBoaCBoaF1baGggaGggfiB%2BXSIpCmNvbnN0IG9wZW5IYXQgPSBzKCJbfiB%2BIH4gfl1bfiB%2BIH4gfl1bfiB%2BIH4gfl1bfiB%2BIG9oIH5dIikKY29uc3QgY2xhcCA9IHMoIlt%2BIH4gfiB%2BXVtjcCB%2BIH4gfl1bfiB%2BIH4gfl1bY3AgfiB%2BIH5dIikKCnN0YWNrKGtpY2ssY2xvc2VkSGF0LG9wZW5IYXQsY2xhcCkuYmFuaygiUm9sYW5kUjgiKQ%3D%3D](https://strudel.cc/#c2V0Y3BtKDk4LzQpCgovLyBEZWZpbmUgZWFjaCBpbnN0cnVtZW50IHBhdHRlcm4KY29uc3Qga2ljayA9IHMoIltiZCBiZCB%2BIH5dW34gfiBiZCB%2BXVtiZCBiZCB%2BIGJkXVt%2BIH4gfiB%2BXSIpCmNvbnN0IGNsb3NlZEhhdCA9IHMoIltoaCBoaCBoaCBoaF1bIGhoIGhoIGhoIGhoXVtoaCBoaCBoaCBoaF1baGggaGggfiB%2BXSIpCmNvbnN0IG9wZW5IYXQgPSBzKCJbfiB%2BIH4gfl1bfiB%2BIH4gfl1bfiB%2BIH4gfl1bfiB%2BIG9oIH5dIikKY29uc3QgY2xhcCA9IHMoIlt%2BIH4gfiB%2BXVtjcCB%2BIH4gfl1bfiB%2BIH4gfl1bY3AgfiB%2BIH5dIikKCnN0YWNrKGtpY2ssY2xvc2VkSGF0LG9wZW5IYXQsY2xhcCkuYmFuaygiUm9sYW5kUjgiKQ%3D%3D)

The notes are the same; we've just changed the sounds. But this gives each version its own unique character.

The four types of sounds in these grids are among the most commonly used drum sounds in many styles of both acoustic and electronic music. Here's a bit more about them:

## **Kick**

![image.png](What%20are%20these%20sounds/image.png)

Also called a *bass drum*, an acoustic kick is struck by a pedal with a beater attached, and is played by the drummer's foot. Electronic versions of this sound are sometimes made to sustain much longer than the relatively short sound produced by a physical drum.

In Strudel, kick is denoted as `bd` (bass drum)

Compare an electronic and an acoustic kick:

[https://strudel.cc/#c2V0Y3BtKDk4LzQpCgovLyBFbGVjdHJpYyBLaWNrIHVzaW5nIFJvbGFuZFRSOTA5CmNvbnN0IGVsZWN0cmljID0gcygiW2JkIGJkIH4gfl1bfiB%2BIGJkIH5dW2JkIGJkIH4gYmRdW34gfiB%2BIH5dIikuYmFuaygiUm9sYW5kVFI5MDkiKQoKLy8gQWNvdXN0aWMgS2ljayB1c2luZyBSb2xhbmRSOApjb25zdCBhY291c3RpYyA9IHMoIltiZCBiZCB%2BIH5dW34gfiBiZCB%2BXVtiZCBiZCB%2BIGJkXVt%2BIH4gfiB%2BXSIpLmJhbmsoIlJvbGFuZFI4IikKCmFycmFuZ2UoCiAgWzEsIGVsZWN0cmljXSwKICBbMSwgYWNvdXN0aWNdCikK](https://strudel.cc/#c2V0Y3BtKDk4LzQpCgovLyBFbGVjdHJpYyBLaWNrIHVzaW5nIFJvbGFuZFRSOTA5CmNvbnN0IGVsZWN0cmljID0gcygiW2JkIGJkIH4gfl1bfiB%2BIGJkIH5dW2JkIGJkIH4gYmRdW34gfiB%2BIH5dIikuYmFuaygiUm9sYW5kVFI5MDkiKQoKLy8gQWNvdXN0aWMgS2ljayB1c2luZyBSb2xhbmRSOApjb25zdCBhY291c3RpYyA9IHMoIltiZCBiZCB%2BIH5dW34gfiBiZCB%2BXVtiZCBiZCB%2BIGJkXVt%2BIH4gfiB%2BXSIpLmJhbmsoIlJvbGFuZFI4IikKCmFycmFuZ2UoCiAgWzEsIGVsZWN0cmljXSwKICBbMSwgYWNvdXN0aWNdCikK)

You can get a list of which sound bank sounds acoustic or electric by copy-pasting all the sound bank list in Strudel drum_machines and asking ChatGPT like below

https://chatgpt.com/share/6910f481-5c58-8009-8231-a3329597ef5a

## Clap

![image.png](What%20are%20these%20sounds/image%201.png)

This is the sound of one or more people clapping their hands. Today, electronic, stylized versions of this sound (like the one used here) are much more common than actual recordings of handclaps.

In Strudel, a clap is denoted as `cp`

## Snare

![image.png](What%20are%20these%20sounds/image%202.png)

A *snare drum* is struck with a drum stick, and produces a short, bright sound. A set of wires (called *snares*) is stretched across a *drum head* at the bottom of the drum. The vibration of the bottom drum head against the snares produces the drum's characteristic "cracking" tone.

Claps, snares, and other "sharp" or "bright" sounds are often used in similar ways in drum patterns.

In Strudel, a snare is denoted as `sd`

Compare an electronic clap and an acoustic snare sound:

[https://strudel.cc/#%3D%3D](https://strudel.cc/#%3D%3D)

## **Closed Hat and Open Hat**

![image.png](What%20are%20these%20sounds/image%203.png)

These are two different sounds created by an instrument called the hihat. Hihats are a pair of small cymbals mounted on a stand. The top cymbal is attached to a rod that is raised and lowered with a foot pedal. Hihats are "closed" when the drummer's foot is down, which presses the cymbals together. They are "open" when the drummer's foot is raised and the cymbals are not touching. On an acoustic drumset, there is a huge range of states in between the open and closed position, and each state creates a different type of sound.

Closed hihats are denoted as `hh` and Open hihats are denoted as `oh`

Try comparing the sounds

[https://strudel.cc/#](https://strudel.cc/#)

## Try it all together

Feel free to play around!

### Electric Sounds

[https://strudel.cc/#%3D%3D](https://strudel.cc/#%3D%3D)

### Acoustic Sounds

[https://strudel.cc/#%3D%3D](https://strudel.cc/#%3D%3D)

## Sample sounds in Strudel Sound Library

If you take a look at Strudel Sounds Library, for example when you search “RolandTR909”

![image.png](What%20are%20these%20sounds/image%204.png)

There is a number beside the sound name.

For example, `rolandtr909_bd(4)` means there are 4 different samples of `bd` sound in RolandTR909 sound bank.

We can refer to which sound we want to use by writing `{sound}:{sample_number}` , for example `bd:0`, `bd:1` , `bd:2` , and `bd:3` . If we leave out the number `bd` , then it picks `bd:0`

Remember, it starts with zero

Now, try and play around with this example

[https://strudel.cc/#](https://strudel.cc/#)

These are all hi-hats from `RolandTR909`, but you can see the difference in sound between each sample available in `RolandTR909` hi-hats.

## Other sounds

There are also other sounds in drums that we’re not covering now, such as crash `cr` , ride `rd`, high tom `ht`, medium tom `mt`, low tom `lt`. Feel free to play it around in strudel as well.

![image.png](What%20are%20these%20sounds/image%205.png)

## Did you notice?

If you play a closed hihat while an open hihat sound is still being heard, the closed sound will "win," and stop the open sound immediately. This matches the way hihats behave in the real world; the hihat can't be open and closed at the same time. Hihats work this way throughout these lessons.

### Reference

https://learningmusic.ableton.com/make-beats/what-are-these-sounds.html
